timeline.bodyText:
Not a big fan of these here.
ImmutableSet.of(..) may be the better choice.
timeline.author: szarnekow
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@

timeline.bodyText: Is there an implicit assumption that these are strings of the length 1?
timeline.author: szarnekow
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,99 @@
+/**
+ * Copyright (c) 2015, 2020 itemis AG (http://www.itemis.eu) and others.
+ * This program and the accompanying materials are made available under the
+ * terms of the Eclipse Public License 2.0 which is available at
+ * http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-2.0.
+ * 
+ * SPDX-License-Identifier: EPL-2.0
+ */
+package org.eclipse.xtext.ide.editor.bracketmatching;
+
+import org.eclipse.xtext.xbase.lib.util.ToStringBuilder;
+
+/**
+ * Defines a single pair of braces which need to be matched when editing code.
+ * 
+ * @author kosyakov - Initial contribution and API
+ */
+public class BracePair {
+	/**
+	 * The length of a left brace should be one character for Eclipse.
+	 */
+	private final String leftBrace;
+
+	/**
+	 * The length of a right brace should be one character for Eclipse.
+	 */
+	private final String rightBrace;
+
+	/**
+	 * True if the brace is structural. Structural braces have higher priority than regular braces: they are matched
+	 * with each other even if there are unmatched braces of other types between them, and an opening non-structural
+	 * brace is not matched with a closing one if one of them is outside a pair of matched structural braces and another
+	 * is outside. In Java code, the curly braces are structural.
+	 * 
+	 * It is ignored by Eclipse.
+	 */
+	private final boolean structural;
+
+	public BracePair(String leftBrace, String rightBrace, boolean structural) {
+		this.leftBrace = leftBrace;

replies.bodyText: no idea. did not look into.
replies.author: cdietrich

replies.bodyText: You could do a Preconditions.checkArgument(leftBrace.length() == 1);. At least the javadoc of the fields assumes these are length 1.
replies.author: tivervac

timeline.bodyText:
Stylistic: T extends Object is redundant.
Also: this should probably be Function<? super ILSA.Context, ? extends T>
timeline.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText: this would break clients like LanguageServerImpl
replies.author: cdietrich

timeline.bodyText:
Not strictly related: There is no removeBuildListener.
Should we add an empty default method + impl in our code?
timeline.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText: we would but noone would call
replies.author: cdietrich

replies.bodyText: I think that's because we don't have any meaningful execute commands in our code base.
replies.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText:
I would very much prefer this. I've had to remove calls like this before when working on LSP.
People don't call the methods just because they're not there.
replies.author: tivervac

timeline.author: szarnekow
szarnekow

timeline.bodyText: A generated toString may be handy for debugging
timeline.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText: am not sure if toString on the resource and element would be good
replies.author: cdietrich

replies.bodyText: Yes. I'd assume that the canceled flag will be set by a thread different from the current worker thread. Otherwise the worker would just bail out.
replies.author: szarnekow

+package org.eclipse.xtext.ide.server;
+
+import org.eclipse.xtext.ide.server.ILanguageServerAccess;
+
+/**
+ * Interface for language specific extensions to the LSP. Implementors should use {link JsonRpcNotification} and {link
+ * JsonRpcRequest} annotations.
+ * 
+ * @author Sven Efftinge - Initial contribution and API
+ */
+public interface ILanguageServerExtension {
+	/**
+	 * The same jsonrpc method might be supported by multiple languages and only the actual invocation might reveal is a
+	 * language wants to handle it, based on e.g. a uri in the parameter.
+	 * 
+	 * To indicate that a request is not handled, this exception should be thrown by the service.
+	 */
+	static final RuntimeException NOT_HANDLED_EXCEPTION = new UnsupportedOperationException("not handled");
+
+	/**
+	 * the language server provides a access to language server documents, resources and build events.
